document.title: FINAL - Integrated Social Studies Standards K-8

7F2A498265ED4BF6BA14AC657748EDE4.description: Examine the significance of Lee's surrender.

B07D9DBEFF00408B9D9A04D8B96124E3.description: Compare significant Civil War battles and events and their effects on civilian populations.

9414E4C37A67485491E680414C388A81.description: Compare Union and Confederate strengths and weaknesses.

47B98DF2201E407CA7F8F00B22EAAC98.description: Identify the division (Confederate and Union States, Border states, western territories) of the United States at the outbreak of the Civil War.

4CD60B2F4FA34B29B29BE12FE42988E0.description: Identify the relationship and division of powers between the federal government and state governments.

737FD896A5B640FAB6364CFAD5656B01.description: Explain major domestic and international economic, military, political, and socio-cultural events of Abraham Lincoln's presidency.

4C1AE4246A5D4517BCC74B0745DCE125.description: Explain the causes and consequences of the Civil War, including the practice of enslavement, sectionalism, the abolitionist movement, religiously motivated concerns, states' rights, and the balance of power in the Senate.

2CFD122877804D9CA580817EA276F86B.description: Standard 9: Examine the causes, course, and consequences of the Civil War on American people.

8FB65D664AC44150ABE95677623D19E4.description: Explain the consequences of landmark Supreme Court decisions (McCulloch v. Maryland [1819], Gibbons v. Odgen [1824], Cherokee Nation v. Georgia [1831], and Worcester v. Georgia [1832]) significant to this era of American history.

4EF42D53B30D4F73B99AA5106FBE8874.description: Examine the aspects of the daily life of enslaved people including plantation life, resistance efforts, and the role of their spiritual system, including how enslaved people developed a unique understanding of Christianity that was rooted in their experience.

DB330B1ABF43498890171F9C28F117B2.description: Explain the causes and consequences of industrial growth during this time period; i.e. textile industry, subsequent effect on children and women, environmental impacts, and impacts on enslaved people.

2FAE3E470FFD4626B95B0DC2BD9A42CF.description: Identify technological improvements (inventions/inventors) that contributed to industrial growth in the areas of transportation, textiles, agriculture.

5E54D32ED257442A9A3A699F059567C7.description: Discuss the impact of westward expansion on cultural practices and migration patterns of indigenous nations and enslaved African populations.

9B41A16DF81F47BCB51ACE3B61D93AF9.description: Identify key ideas and influences of Jacksonian democracy.

A77283D99CB54EBEAF8278D25DBC98BF.description: Describe the debate surrounding the spread of slavery into western territories and Florida.

A03DE5A7F60C4FECBD34F3800503BAFE.description: Examine the causes, course, and consequences of United States westward expansion and its growing diplomatic assertiveness (War of 1812, Convention of 1818, Adams-Onis Treaty, Missouri Compromise, Monroe Doctrine, Trail of Tears, Texas annexation, Manifest Destiny, Oregon Territory, Mexican American War/Mexican Cession, California Gold Rush, Compromise of 1850, Kansas Nebraska Act, Gadsden Purchase).

EDF97036196F4D9F862C91883ECCE4EC.description: Standard 8: Demonstrate an understanding of the domestic and international causes, course, and consequences of westward expansion.

A0A4754442E44E61BA47645346597B87.description: Find New Testament examples of persons responding to God's call to serve God and others.

3D6697CF27E04C478E20695B8DD9429E.description: Understand one's responsibility and ways to serve other people, especially those in most need.

BEF02C39290E4DC3AAAE028BE5828677.description: Examine this time period (1763-1815) from the perspective of historically under-represented groups (children, indentured servants,indigenous people, enslaved people, women, and the working class).

AF7300BCAA2045FA8F6502DC1F08ED92.description: Explain major domestic and international economic, military, political, and socio-cultural events of Thomas Jefferson's presidency including the acquisition of the Louisiana Territory.

66EDF8F07A6E4537A5A3D2857850C637.description: Examine the Constitutional amendment process as it relates to the 11th and 12th amendments.

41FEEFF0A8B54357974F0A534F34FD9A.description: Explain major domestic and international economic, military, political, and socio-cultural events of John Adams's presidency.

7EDBCAFD9A8F4E118CE288A9298F79DB.description: Examine the influences of George Washington's presidency in the formation of the new nation.

32DBDD099CB5498EB2EB7FFF79F88F86.description: Standard 7:  Recognize the impacts of the decisions of the first presidents and the policies of their administrations on the continuing formation of the United States.

0CBADBD2841A4B6FB019485CA1640324.description: Distinguish how the Constitution safeguards and limits individual rights.

AA5185E546D645F19E54839FAD3C2F84.description: Evaluate rights contained in the Bill of Rights and other amendments to the Constitution (comparison - Ten Commandments and the Beatitudes as a guide to common good).

3E0ED967CAE542D7AB85AFA08EAF18BB.description: Standard 6: Evaluate the roles, rights, and responsibilities of United States citizens, and determine methods of active participation in society, government, and the political system.

BDCDF20BED184952857D1C32DB018BFF.description: Analyze the structure, functions, and processes of the legislative, executive, and judicial branches (Marbury v. Madison).

78EC508261DB4FE49161A34F53F3E65B.description: Illustrate the structure and function (three branches of government established in Articles I, II, and III with corresponding powers) of government in the United States as established in the Constitution.

33B0B12C1B17429E9944633985D67658.description: Define how the rule of law influences the development of the American legal, political, and governmental systems.

333B1E7A825B4602860378FD1B74C14E.description: Explain the viewpoints of the Federalists and the Anti-Federalists regarding the ratification of the Constitution and inclusion of a bill of rights.

2C5E7886249D401FA932899D5009EAF0.description: Describe how the Constitution limits the powers of government through separation of powers and checks and balances.

A1F4710D2A694D95823AD50EFF867FEE.description: Evaluate the intentions of the Preamble of the Constitution as it relates to the goals of the new governement.

68AC119FD6DD4ACEB8DE139F413E82A9.description: Standard 5:  Demonstrate an understanding of the principles, functions, and organization of government.

6A28D09767454AB6B1F37EA93CDE1DAF.description: Analyze support and opposition (Federalists, Federalist Papers, Anti-Federalists, Bill of Rights) to ratification of the U.S. Constitution.

D8CACDD9D5CD45C780A31CAC15BC0F1C.description: Examine the course and consequences of the Constitutional Convention (New Jersey Plan, Virginia Plan, Great Compromise, Three-Fifths Compromise, compromises regarding taxation and slave trade, Electoral College, state vs. federal power, empowering a president).

5FB2AC01C1E4409AB436307D5FDAD921.description: Identify how the weaknesses of the Articles of Confederation led to the writing of the Constitution.

428DB5240CCE46D5957B372B0B00A852.description: Evaluate the structure, strengths, and weaknesses of the Articles of Confederation and its aspects that led to the Constitutional Convention.

6F992BE06FCA4059818877E1EDDC3B8B.description: Understand one's responsibility  and ways to serve other people, especially those in most need.

B1FEEC1A8FAF433AAB7A76B85CE876E2.description: Analyze the ideas (natural rights, role of the government) and complaints set forth in the Declaration of Independence.

2E554B4F58034D7BB0F53FA00426A2DA.description: Describe how English policies and responses to colonial concerns led to the writing of the Declaration of Independence.

89302C32845F4D019362F6988BE8FD52.description: Standard 4: Demonstrate an understanding of the origins and purposes of government, law, and the American political system.

D15C730CC2C34B92BCFD11D38B4E3751.description: Examine individuals and groups that affected political and social motivations during the American Revolution.

11221321B751441286B70BC6057BDAB6.description: Examine the structure, content, and consequences of the Declaration of Independence.

97552528E3794F528657424C427C77DD.description: Examine the causes, course, and consequences of the American Revolution.

B18BC838871C4605B6020705A0E25305.description: State the importance of Christians taking an active part in public life building the Kingdom of God and promoting the common good.

BE8174F7857042DD8EC7D275310AA6EE.description: Describe the influence of individuals on social and political developments during the Revolutionary era.

9D1D477F0A654EA48F1E92F13AFE1FED.description: Examine the contributions of influential groups to both the American and British war efforts during the American Revolutionary War and their effects on the outcome of the war.

3CD97A934D7A43FF97B514E2078D100E.description: Recognize the contributions of the Founding Fathers (John Adams, Sam Adams, Benjamin Franklin, John Hancock, Alexander Hamilton, Thomas Jefferson, James Madison, George Mason, George Washington) during American Revolutionary efforts.

A48A951D42E24B58815ED6AF38E5FEF9.description: Explain American colonial reaction to British policy from 1763 - 1774.

C48485780C8B419089CF0497084D2641.description: Explain the consequences of the French and Indian War in British policies for the American colonies from 1763 - 1774.

7D2084BA5C534BBE9344F6F02E5A2D35.description: Standard 3:   Demonstrate an understanding of the causes, course, and consequences of the American Revolution and the founding principles of our nation.

8166803F89694869BABE4AA67254B5FE.description: Trace the impact that the Magna Carta, English Bill of Rights, Mayflower Compact, and Thomas Paine's "Common Sense" had on colonists' views of government.

64605DD2569B4761A362CA0D7481679F.description: Understand how God's Natual Law is perfected in the Sermon on the Mount and leads us to what we must do and what we must avoid.

1EAE8E691B1D4624A9F616004BBA2C43.description: Describe how God's Natural Law helps us listen to our own sacred story to follow Jesus Christ.

0004C876EBBC417B81A679C054B436C0.description: Recognize how Enlightenment ideas including Montesquieu's view of separation of power and John Locke's theories related to natural law and how Locke's social contract influenced the Founding Fathers.

6ECBB42BF19D415BB79C93133576B308.description: Standard 2:   Demonstrate an understanding of the origins and purposes of government, law, and the American political system.

D93114CA8DCC43AF80460ACCB24EC2D9.description: Describe the contributions of key groups (Africans, indigenous people, women, and children) to the society and culture of colonial America.

4ADDC7D528B745BE9C08222786E9D123.description: Examine the causes, course, and consequences of the French and Indian War.

19FAF301727F43E98F01905190E4D8E4.description: Discuss the impact of colonial settlement on Native American populations.

720AECF57A0C4D21890C6C5D7DA8BC19.description: Identify the impact of key colonial figures on the economic, political, and social development of the colonies.

7A81943CCB1C4020B2A412177E41F2FF.description: Differentiate economic systems of New England, Middle and Southern colonies including indentured servants and enslaved people as labor sources.

6D5E166FA162485A9FC323A45C47BF4A.description: Compare the characteristics of the New England, Middle, and Southern colonies.

28D5582CFB8A4C2CB78A92AAC44596D9.description: Standard 1:   Examine the causes, course, and consequences of British settlement in the American colonies.

325E2A362F2E458DBD2FD91372DF4CAA.description: Strand: Colonial American History and Government

92A0C1AC67EC4A35BFA3D71C5AA93519.description: Explain how the principles of a market and mixed economy contributed to the develop the United States into a democratic nation.

C1C7C37D6FDB4F76AD683424784DAF79.description: Standard 1:   Understand the fundamental concepts relevant to the development of a market economy.

E585F53B0687428F8C548FDB74663D47.description: Use maps to describe the location, abundance, and variety of natural resources in North America.

7A36791025C94EAAABC7B1C3F51EB7E9.description: Standard 3:   Understand the relationships between the Earth's ecosystems and the populations that dwell within them.

78DE9B1B3BC34DDA8038C61E621D9BFD.description: Explain how major physical characteristics, natural resources, climate, and absolute and relative location have influenced settlement, economies, and inter-governmental relations in North America.

025A513DE2DE485B99A5ECB778C52AA4.description: Standard 2:   Understand physical and cultural characteristics of places.

8E92804F80AA45199030F2330ED74473.description: Interpret maps to identify geopolitical divisions and boundaries of places in North America.

F8974513D0854B92AF58372E6C273921.description: Locate on a world map the territories and protectorates of the United States of America.

451ACA87B70D454295156DA1C7CE1880.description: Locate the fifty states and their capital cities in addition to the nation's capital on a map.

3D4601424C0A4F3D9314C96DD6B05BCF.description: Standard 1:   Understand how to use maps and other geographic representations, tools, and technology to report information.

202D467413D2444F96281EF8D9852224.description: View historic events through the eyes of those who were there as shown in their art, writings, music, and artifacts.

119ECD28BF2B4079AD2788F91A2C8A57.description: Compare interpretations of key events and issues throughout American History.

2A0E2CE899DD4C5FA21D87B7A8A45989.description: Identify, within both primary and secondary sources, the author, audience, format, and purpose of significant historical documents.

0C2F9C1314E84ADCA9B6B2D04BEDD40B.description: Differentiate fact from opinion, utilize appropriate historical research and fiction/nonfiction support materials.

8D33E109F2614F6688F4658DC5E1D48E.description: Analyze current events relevant to American History topics through a variety of electronic and print media resources.

C603DA3DE22F40939BE2F3A95D7EBD0D.description: Analyze charts, graphs, maps, photographs and timelines; analyze political cartoons; determine cause and effect.

8DEE56B6F4F0443CB25D4984A2EF8932.description: Provide supporting details for an answer from text, interview for oral history, check validity of information from research/text, and identify strong vs. weak arguments.

C965BE0B83D64DD9A7981AC6F769966D.description: Standard 1:   Use research and inquiry skills to analyze American History using primary and secondary sources.
